verses.text: My son, do not forget my teaching, but let your heart keep my commands,
verses.comment: Wisdom is presented as something to be treasured in the heart, echoing the call in Deuteronomy to keep God’s words inwardly, not just outwardly. This anticipates the interior grace written on the heart in the New Covenant (cf. Jer. 31:33).

verses.text: for they will add to you length of days, years of life and peace.
verses.comment: The promise of a long and peaceful life mirrors the commandment to honor parents, connecting obedience to spiritual authorities with divine blessing.

verses.text: Let not steadfast love and faithfulness forsake you; bind them around your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart.
verses.comment: The language of ‘binding’ and ‘writing on the heart’ foreshadows spiritual sacraments and the internal transformation by the Spirit. Love and faithfulness are not just actions but part of one’s very identity.

verses.text: So you will find favor and good understanding in the sight of God and man.
verses.comment: True spiritual wisdom brings harmony with both God and people, similar to how Jesus grew in wisdom and favor before God and man (Luke 2:52), showing the ideal of holy living impacting both heaven and earth.

verses.text: Trust in the Lord with all your heart and do not depend on your own understanding.
verses.comment: A warning not to set human judgment over divine wisdom. This reflects Jesus’ call to radical trust (cf. Matt. 6:25-34).

verses.text: In all your ways acknowledge him, and he will make straight your paths.
verses.comment: ‘Straight paths’ suggests being led by God’s divine guidance. This idea of the Lord ‘making straight’ refers spiritually to a life aligned with God’s redemptive plan.

verses.text: Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear the Lord and turn from evil.
verses.comment: The path to wisdom runs counter to pride. To ‘fear the Lord’ recalls the biblical theme that wisdom is found in humility and reverence toward God.

verses.text: It will be healing to your body and refreshment to your bones.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings physical and spiritual wholeness, echoing the restoration that comes from a right relationship with God. The language points to both bodily and spiritual healing.

verses.text: Honor the Lord with your wealth and with the firstfruits of all your produce;
verses.comment: Giving to God first signifies the priority God deserves. The practice of firstfruits later finds spiritual fulfillment in the sanctification of all aspects of life to God.

verses.text: then your barns will be filled with plenty, and your vats will be bursting with new wine.
verses.comment: Material abundance is portrayed as a result of faithful giving, but in spiritual interpretation, it also points to the superabundant blessings God provides to those who offer their lives to him.

verses.text: My son, do not despise the Lord’s discipline or be weary of his correction,
verses.comment: God’s correction is an act of love. The New Testament refers to this passage to show God’s fatherly care (cf. Heb. 12:5-6).

verses.text: for the Lord reproves him whom he loves, as a father the son in whom he delights.
verses.comment: God’s discipline is evidence of his love. Correction is a sign of authentic relationship and spiritual sonship (cf. Heb. 12).

verses.text: Blessed is the one who finds wisdom, and the one who gains understanding,
verses.comment: Wisdom is depicted as a great spiritual treasure, anticipating how Christ is later revealed as the true wisdom from God (cf. 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: for the gain from her is better than gain from silver and her profit better than gold.
verses.comment: Earthly riches cannot compare to the lasting value of divine wisdom, which comes only from God.

verses.text: She is more precious than jewels, and nothing you desire can compare with her.
verses.comment: The personification of wisdom anticipates the New Testament development of Christ as the source and fullness of wisdom.

verses.text: Long life is in her right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor.
verses.comment: The blessings associated with wisdom are first temporal, but point toward the honor and eternal life given to those in Christ.

verses.text: Her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are peace.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s ways lead to true peace (shalom), echoing God’s ultimate plan for harmony and fulfillment through the Messiah.

verses.text: She is a tree of life to those who take hold of her; those who hold her fast are called blessed.
verses.comment: The ‘tree of life’ directly references Eden and points forward to its restoration in Revelation. Wisdom gives a foretaste of the eternal life Christ brings.

verses.text: The Lord by... wisdom founded the earth; by understanding he established the heavens;
verses.comment: Creation itself is rooted in God’s wisdom, which becomes a major theme interpreted Christologically in John 1:1–3.

verses.text: by his knowledge the deeps were broken open, and the clouds drop down the dew.
verses.comment: God’s wisdom orders all of creation, including rain for sustenance—a theme echoing God’s ongoing providence.

verses.text: My son, do not let them depart from your eyes—keep sound wisdom and discretion;
verses.comment: Vigilance in holding fast to wisdom is stressed; wisdom requires active seeking and keeping.

verses.text: so they will be life to your soul and adornment to your neck.
verses.comment: Wisdom does not merely preserve physical life, but enlivens the soul, a hint at the spiritual fruit of grace.

verses.text: Then you will walk safely on your way, and your foot will not stumble.
verses.comment: God’s wisdom provides protection along life’s journey, invoking images of angels and divine guardianship.

verses.text: If you lie down, you will not be afraid; when you lie down, your sleep will be sweet.
verses.comment: Spiritual tranquility and rest are given to those who live by wisdom, prefiguring the rest found in Christ (cf. Matt. 11:28-30).

verses.text: Do not be afraid of sudden terror, nor of the ruin of the wicked, when it comes;
verses.comment: The righteous are preserved from fear during times of trouble by trust in God’s providential care.

verses.text: for the Lord will be your confidence and will keep your foot from being caught.
verses.comment: Confidence is rooted not in self, but in the Lord, who delivers from snares and temptation—a theme deepened in the New Testament.

verses.text: Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in your power to do it.
verses.comment: This points to the righteousness and justice incumbent upon all believers, alluding to charity and works of mercy.

verses.text: Do not say to your neighbor, 'Go, and come back, tomorrow I will give it,' when you have it with you.
verses.comment: Delaying to do good when we can help is condemned in both Testaments. Prompt generosity is a core spiritual virtue.

verses.text: Do not plan harm against your neighbor, who dwells trustingly beside you.
verses.comment: Peaceful coexistence and intentional goodwill prefigure Christ’s command to love your neighbor as yourself.

verses.text: Do not quarrel with anyone without reason, if he has done you no harm.
verses.comment: Maintaining peace echoes Jesus’ teaching that peacemakers are blessed and are called children of God.

verses.text: Do not envy a man of violence, and do not choose any of his ways;
verses.comment: Desiring the ways of the wicked is folly; true life is found in peace, not in aggression or worldly power.

verses.text: for the perverse are an abomination to the Lord, but the upright are in his confidence.
verses.comment: Intimacy with God (‘in his confidence’) is reserved for the upright, foreshadowing the relationship of grace restored in Christ.

verses.text: The curse of the Lord is on the house of the wicked, but he blesses the dwelling of the righteous.
verses.comment: This continues the biblical pattern of blessing and curse, which finds fulfillment in Christ’s role as both the bearer of blessing and the one who breaks the curse (cf. Gal. 3:13).

verses.text: Toward the scorners he is scornful, but to the humble he gives favor.
verses.comment: Humility receives divine grace; this echoes the principle repeated in the New Testament—‘God opposes the proud, but gives grace to the humble.’

verses.text: The wise will inherit honor, but fools get only shame.
verses.comment: The wise ultimately share in honor and glory—in the end, participation in Christ’s inheritance, while folly leads to loss.
